marketNews.title: PPN 12% Applies Only to Luxury Goods
marketNews.content: Chairman of Commission XI of the DPR, Mukhamad Misbakhun, on Thursday (5/12) said that the government will still raise the value-added tax (VAT) from 11% to 12% starting January 2025, although he claimed that the increase will only apply to luxury goods. To date, the government has not released the list of luxury goods that will be subject to the higher VAT. According to Deputy Chairman of the DPR, Sufmi Dasco Ahmad, the list of luxury goods subject to 12% VAT will be compiled by the Ministry of Finance. Misbakhun stated that basic goods, education services, health services, banking services, and public services will remain exempt from VAT, in line with existing policy. The government announcement comes amid pressure from business groups and labor unions demanding a postponement of the VAT increase, given the weakening purchasing power of the public. According to a report by Kompas, the burden on society in 2025 will increase due to the limitation of fuel subsidies, as well as the implementation of various levies such as the increase in BPJS Health premium rates, additional mandatory pension fund contributions, and mandatory motor vehicle third‑party liability insurance premiums. In a separate occasion, the Minister of MSMEs, Maman Abdurrahman, said on Thursday (5/12) that the government is reviewing the extension of the final income tax (PPh) rate of 0.5% for MSMEs. Maman also denied rumors that the 0.5% final PPh for MSMEs would end in December 2024. He emphasized that the prevailing provision remains the same, namely 7 years for individual taxpayers and 4 years for corporate taxpayers. Key Takeaway: The selective VAT increase on luxury goods is a government compromise to raise state revenue while preserving the purchasing power of lower‑middle‑class consumers. It generally provides relief to sectors/companies targeting the lower‑middle market, but may negatively affect those targeting the upper‑middle segment. The definition and list of "luxury goods" released by the government will need to be monitored to assess sector‑specific impacts.

marketNews.title: EMTK Purchases 87 Million Shares of SCMA
marketNews.content: - $SCMA: Sun Media Group's subsidiary Surya Citra Media, Elang Mahkota Teknologi (EMTK), bought 87 million SCMA shares at 137 rupiah per share on 4‑5 December 2024. The transaction value was 11.9 billion rupiah. After the transaction, EMTK's ownership in SCMA rose from 60.97% to 61.09%. - $IATA: PT Karya Pacific Investama purchased 6.3 billion IATA shares at 53 rupiah per share on 25 November 2024. The transaction value was 333 billion rupiah. After the transaction, PT Karya Pacific Investama's ownership in IATA increased from 0% to 24.91%. - $PYFA: Pyridam Farma, through its subsidiary Pyfa Australia Pty. Ltd., announced an additional guarantee related to a facility worth 155 million Australian dollars from Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited. The additional guarantee covers approximately 83.8 million ordinary shares that Pyfa Australia holds in Probiotec, any future tradable securities of Probiotec owned by Pyfa Australia, and any existing or future property of Pyfa Australia. The loan from Shanghai Banking Corporation Limited had previously been used by the company to acquire Probiotec. - $GDST: Gunawan Dianjaya Steel will distribute an interim dividend for fiscal year 2024 amounting to 67.2 billion rupiah or 7.5 rupiah per share. The cum‑date on the regular market and negotiations is 13 December 2024, with payment on 30 December 2024. Based on GDST's closing price on Friday (6/12) at 108 rupiah per share, the implied dividend yield is 6.9%. - $WIFI: Solusi Sinergi Digital announced the appointment of Shannedy Ong as a director of the company, effective today, Friday (6/12). Previously, Shannedy Ong served as Country Managing Director of Qualcomm Indonesia. The appointment was approved in the extraordinary shareholders meeting on Thursday (5/12). - $PANR: Panorama Sentrawisata commissioner Dharmayanto Tirtawisata bought 20 million PANR shares at 550 rupiah per share on 4 December 2024. The transaction value was 11 billion rupiah. After the transaction, Dharmayanto Tirtawisata's ownership in PANR increased from 4.99% to 6.43%. - $ENAK: Champ Resto Indonesia signed an additional loan facility of 199 billion rupiah from Bank Central Asia (BBCA) to support the company's business expansion. - OPEC+ on Thursday (5/12) officially postponed the oil production recovery for three months until April 2025 and extended the recovery period from 12 months to 18 months. Consequently, OPEC+ oil production of 2.2 million barrels per day will be fully restored only in September 2026, with the monthly recovery speed slowing from 180,000 barrels per day to 120,000 barrels per day. The decision marks the third postponement of OPEC+ oil production recovery due to weak demand and a surge in non‑OPEC production. - The Minister of Industry, Agus Gumiwang Kartasasmita, claimed that Apple Inc. will build a factory in Indonesia, though details were not provided. He said coordination with the Ministry of Investment is underway. Earlier, the Minister of Investment, Rosan Roeslani, said Apple had increased its investment proposal to 1 billion US dollars, up 100‑fold from the initial 10 million dollars, to enable iPhone 16 to achieve a 40% domestic component content (TKDN) certification. - Bank Indonesia reported that Indonesia's foreign exchange reserves at the end of November 2024 slightly fell to 150.2 billion US dollars (vs. October 2024: 151.2 billion US dollars). This level equals about 6.5 months of import financing or 6.3 months of import and external debt service, well above the international adequacy standard of roughly three months of imports. Bank Indonesia assessed that the reserves can support external sector resilience and maintain macro‑economic and financial system stability. - The Chairman of the Indonesian General Insurance Association, Budi Herawan, said the government will implement third‑party liability (TPL) insurance in the second half of 2025 as originally planned, though he could not confirm whether it would be fully implemented in 2025 due to potential burden on the public. He noted that a draft TPL insurance regulation already exists at the Ministry of Finance. - The Minister of State‑Owned Enterprises, Erick Thohir, said the government is preparing a five‑year roadmap to reduce airline ticket tariffs, aiming to make air travel more affordable. Previously, ticket prices were reduced by 10% for domestic flights during the Christmas and New Year period (19 December 2024 – 3 January 2025). - The Head of the Police Traffic Corps, Inspector General Pol. Aan Suhanan, projected that public movement during the Christmas 2024 and New Year 2025 period would increase by 2.8% year‑on‑year to 110.67 million people, based on a survey by the Ministry of Transportation. - $ITIC: Indonesian Tobacco (ITIC) CEO Djonny Saksono bought approximately 4.5 million ITIC shares at an average price of about 261 rupiah per share on 2‑4 December 2024. The transaction value was about 1.2 billion rupiah. After the transaction, Saksono's ownership in ITIC rose from 67.19% to 67.67%.
